questions.question: The power to dismiss and exercise disciplinary control over officers on GL 07 and above in the Federal Civil Service is vested in:
options: The Permanent Secretary/CEO
The Office of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
The Ministerial Tenders Board
questions.explanation: The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC) is vested with the power to dismiss and exercise disciplinary control over officers in the Federal Civil Service, particularly those on GL 07 and above, as mandated by Rule 100102.

questions.question: The principle that ensures government policies continue to be implemented regardless of transient changes in political leadership is known as:
options: Neutrality
Permanence
Meritocracy
Anonymity
questions.explanation: Permanence ensures that the civil service continues its functions despite political changes.

questions.question: Appointments into all grades in Parastatals must be based on merit, credibility, and equal opportunity with due regard to the:
options: Political party manifesto
Federal Character Principle
Seniority rule
Budgetary appropriation
questions.explanation: Rule 170302 mandates that appointments must be fair and open, ensuring merit, credibility, and equal opportunity for all with due regard to the Federal Character Principle.

questions.question: Who is constitutionally empowered to present the annual budget to the National Assembly for legislative approval?
options: The Minister of Finance
The Accountant-General of the Federation
The President
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: Section 81 of the Constitution mandates the President to present the budget to the National Assembly.

questions.question: The constitutional provision that all government funds must be centralized into a specific main account for transparency and control refers to the:
options: Contingencies Fund
Development Fund
Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF)
Replacement Reserve Fund
questions.explanation: The Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) is the main account into which all government revenues are paid.

questions.question: The authority responsible for the audit of government accounts and reporting findings to the National Assembly is the:
options: Accountant-General of the Federation
Auditor-General for the Federation (AuGF)
Minister of Finance
Internal Auditor
questions.explanation: The Auditor-General for the Federation (AuGF) audits public accounts and reports to the National Assembly (implied by references to Audit Report and legislative oversight).

questions.question: The power of the National Assembly to make laws on matters such as currency and defense is drawn from which list in the Constitution?
options: Concurrent Legislative List
Residual Powers List
Exclusive Legislative List
Judicial Review List
questions.explanation: Federal-only matters are typically found in the Exclusive Legislative List.

questions.question: Who is designated as the Chief Accounting Officer personally responsible for the control, custody, and disbursement of funds within a Ministry?
options: The Minister
The Permanent Secretary/DG
The Accountant-General of the Federation
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary or DG of an MDA serves as the Accounting Officer responsible for expenditure control, record keeping, and compliance (FR 104).

questions.question: The three core values emphasized for civil servants in the Civil Service Handbook are secrecy, efficiency, and:
options: Nepotism
Loyalty
Partisanship
Insolvency
questions.explanation: The handbook emphasizes secrecy, efficiency, and loyalty as core values of civil servants.

questions.question: The constitutional body that collects and verifies asset declarations from public officers to enforce ethical standards is the:
options: Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC)
Independent Corrupt Practices Commission (ICPC)
Code of Conduct Bureau (CCB)
Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
questions.explanation: The Code of Conduct Bureau (CCB) receives asset declarations and monitors compliance with ethical standards.

questions.question: The doctrine of **Separation of Powers** divides governmental authority between which three arms?
options: Federal, State, and Local
The Public, the Civil Service, and the Military
The Judiciary, the Executive, and the Legislature
The Minister, the Permanent Secretary, and the Director
questions.explanation: The doctrine of separation of powers divides authority between the Judiciary, Executive, and Legislature.

questions.question: The **Oath of Allegiance/Oath of Office** signed by an officer commits them to uphold and serve faithfully according to the:
options: Public Service Rules
Constitution of Nigeria
Ministerial Directives
Financial Regulations
questions.explanation: The Oath of Allegiance/Oath of Office is a binding promise to uphold the Constitution and serve faithfully.

questions.question: Which body ensures that recruitment and disciplinary standards are maintained across the Federal Civil Service?
options: Budget Office of the Federation (BOF)
Debt Management Office (DMO)
Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
National Population Commission (NPC)
questions.explanation: The FCSC manages appointments and discipline within the service.

questions.question: The PSR 2021 mandates that matters not covered in its provisions should be referred to whom for appropriate direction?
options: The Minister of Justice
The National Assembly
The Head of Service
The Permanent Secretary
questions.explanation: Matters not covered in the PSR should be referred to the Head of Service for appropriate direction (Rule 16.10).

questions.question: Who must approve the re-engagement of retired officers into career posts, whose remuneration is based on negotiable terms?
options: The Minister of Finance
The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
The Permanent Secretary
questions.explanation: Re-engagement typically requires approval by the FCSC for career posts (Rule 020412).

questions.question: Which principle guarantees that civil servants serve all citizens and political parties without personal or political preference?
options: Anonymity
Neutrality
Permanence
Centralization
questions.explanation: Impartiality guarantees that civil servants serve all citizens fairly without political or personal bias.

questions.question: The civil service hierarchy structures staff into categories based on professional disciplines and levels of responsibility, known as:
options: Committees and Boards
Regions and Zones
Grades and Cadres
Parastatals and Agencies
questions.explanation: The civil service is structured into Grades and Cadres.

questions.question: The official document used to publish laws, appointments, and constitutional changes in Nigeria is the:
options: National Gazette
Annual Appropriation Act
Budget Call Circular
Public Complaints Report
questions.explanation: The Official Gazette is the formal government publication used to publish laws, appointments, and constitutional changes.

questions.question: In the case of conflict between the English version and a local language version of the PSR, which version prevails?
options: The local language version
The English version
The version preferred by the OHCSF
The version with the earliest commencement date
questions.explanation: The English version of the PSR prevails in case of conflict with local language versions (Rule 16.19).

questions.question: The core constitutional and legal document that outlines civil liberties and protections for citizens, including the right to fair hearing, is:
options: The Public Procurement Act
The Financial Regulations
The Constitution (Chapter IV)
The Civil Service Handbook
questions.explanation: Chapter IV of the Constitution outlines civil liberties and protections, known as fundamental rights.

subcategories.name: Legal Frameworks & Statutory Compliance
subcategories.description: Applicable laws and compliance obligations in public service.

questions.question: Which legal framework provides the guidelines for prudence, transparency, and accountability in the management of public finance in Nigeria?
options: Public Procurement Act (PPA)
Fiscal Responsibility Act (FRA)
Official Secrets Act
Pension Reform Act
questions.explanation: The Fiscal Responsibility Act provides the legal framework for prudent management of public finances in Nigeria.

questions.question: Section 58 of the Public Procurement Act (PPA) prescribes penalties for offenses such as bid rigging, collusion, and procurement fraud, including dismissal or:
options: Payment of a minor fine to the MDA
Reduction in salary only
Criminal charges including imprisonment
Transfer to a remote station
questions.explanation: Section 58 prescribes imprisonment and fines for procurement-related fraud. Officers involved also face dismissal as serious misconduct.

questions.question: The legal principle that prohibits civil servants from disclosing sensitive government information without authorization is enforced by the:
options: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA)
Official Secrets Act
Public Complaints Act
Code of Conduct Bureau Act
questions.explanation: The Official Secrets Act enforces secrecy requirements for civil servants handling official matters.

questions.question: Which body is empowered to blacklist or debar contracting firms found guilty of corrupt practices or fraudulent misrepresentation during a bidding process?
options: The Auditor-General of the Federation (AuGF)
The Bureau of Public Procurement (BPP)
The Permanent Secretary/CEO
The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
questions.explanation: Section 57 empowers the BPP to blacklist bidders for engaging in corrupt practices.

questions.question: In a disciplinary inquiry, documentary evidence cannot be used against the officer unless he is given open access thereto, ensuring the principle of:
options: Anonymity
Neutrality
Fair Hearing (Natural Justice)
Permanence
questions.explanation: No documentary evidence shall be used against the officer unless he has previously been supplied with a copy or given open access thereto (Rule 100307(vii)) [36-38].

questions.question: The mandatory pre-qualification requirement for bidders, ensuring they have fulfilled tax obligations to the Federal Government, is the submission of a valid:
options: Letter of intent
Tax Clearance Certificate (TCC)
Political Party Membership Card
Local Government Identification Letter
questions.explanation: Section 16 of the PPA requires contractors to demonstrate eligibility, including fulfilling tax obligations.

questions.question: The penalty of **Surcharge** is imposed on an officer to recover:
options: Administrative processing fees
The exact amount of financial loss caused by the officer's negligence or fault
Future salary increments
Legal defense costs
questions.explanation: Surcharge is the recovery of government losses from the officer's pay, applied when the loss is due to the officer‚Äôs fault or negligence.

questions.question: Which legal principle in procurement mandates strict adherence to legal and procedural requirements in awarding contracts to guarantee transparency?
options: Invitation to Treat
Due Process
Caveat Emptor
Locus Standi
questions.explanation: Due Process mandates strict adherence to legal and procedural requirements in awarding contracts [41-43].

questions.question: The use of e-procurement systems (PPA Section 38) in public procurement is primarily aimed at enhancing:
options: Manual processing and paperwork
Efficiency and transparency
Political patronage
Secrecy and restricted bidding
questions.explanation: E-procurement enhances efficiency and transparency.

questions.question: An officer must promptly report a criminal charge or the outcome of such charge to whom, under pain of disciplinary action?
options: The Minister of Justice
His Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office
The Police Commissioner
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
questions.explanation: An Officer must promptly report a criminal charge or the outcome of such charge to his Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office (Rule 100409).

questions.question: Which specific PPA Section prohibits procurement without approved budgetary provision and availability of funds?
options: Section 21 (PPC)
Section 14 (Appropriation)
Section 30 (Evaluation)
Section 42 (Emergency)
questions.explanation: Section 14 prohibits procurement without approved budgetary provision and funds in place.

questions.question: The practice of illegally breaking down a contract into smaller units to circumvent approval limits is explicitly prohibited in the PPA as:
options: Bid Rigging
Contract Variation
Contract Splitting
Collusion
questions.explanation: Contract Splitting is explicitly prohibited (PPA Section 58(4)) as it undermines transparency and circumvents established thresholds.

questions.question: The minimum mandatory period for the archive retention of all procurement records and documents by MDAs is:
options: 1 year
3 years
5 years
10 years
questions.explanation: Procurement documents must be retained for at least 5 years to support potential audits and inquiries (PPA Section 38).

questions.question: The statutory default and preferred method for the procurement of goods, works, and services that promotes transparency and fair competition is:
options: Sole Sourcing
Restricted Bidding
Selective Tendering
Open Competitive Bidding
questions.explanation: Open Competitive Bidding is the default procurement method under Section 24 of the PPA 2007.

questions.question: Who must authorize emergency procurements, subject to later audit and ratification, as required under PPA Section 42?
options: The Permanent Secretary
The Minister
The Head of Civil Service of the Federation
The Accountant-General
questions.explanation: The Minister authorizes emergency procurements, often in line with procurement laws and thresholds, subject to later review.

questions.question: If, during the course of a disciplinary inquiry, further grounds for dismissal are disclosed, the FCSC shall furnish the Officer with:
options: A written notice of termination
A written statement thereof and the same steps shall be taken as prescribed above in respect of the original grounds
A recommendation for compulsory retirement
A transfer letter
questions.explanation: If further grounds are disclosed, the Officer shall be furnished with a written statement thereof and the same steps taken as for the original grounds (Rule 100307(viii)).

questions.question: The rule that the head of the officer‚Äôs department shall not be a member of the board of inquiry tasked with investigating the officer (Rule 100307(v)) safeguards:
options: Anonymity
Fair hearing and judicial neutrality
Segregation of duties
Permanence of the service
questions.explanation: The head of the Officer's department shall not be a member of the board (Rule 100307(v)). This prevents bias and ensures a fair hearing.

questions.question: To ensure maximum transparency, the process of bid opening for public tenders must be conducted:
options: Only by the Ministerial Tenders Board (MTB)
In secrecy to protect prices
Publicly, with all bidders or their representatives invited
After the contract award is finalized
questions.explanation: Bid Opening must be conducted publicly, with all bidders invited and minutes recorded.

questions.question: The final check that confirms goods or services were delivered satisfactorily before any payment is processed is documented by the:
options: Local Purchase Order (LPO)
Job Completion Certificate (JCC)
Stores Receipt Voucher (SRV)
Virement Warrant
questions.explanation: No payment is processed without the Job Completion Certificate (JCC), which confirms that work was done or goods were received.

questions.question: Which PPA Section requires bid opening to be conducted in public?
options: Section 19
Section 27
Section 30
Section 32
questions.explanation: Section 27 requires that bid opening must be done publicly to ensure fairness and transparency.

questions.question: The mandatory requirement that bidders must not be in receivership, bankruptcy, or insolvency is contained in PPA:
options: Section 12
Section 16
Section 24
Section 40
questions.explanation: Section 16 states that eligible contractors must not be in receivership, bankruptcy, or insolvency.

questions.question: What is the maximum penalty for an officer convicted of a felony (criminal offense) in addition to possible automatic dismissal?
options: Transfer to a non-sensitive post
Imprisonment and/or fine
Mandatory study leave
Reduction in salary for six months
questions.explanation: Serious offenses, especially fraud/corruption (PPA Section 58), lead to dismissal and criminal charges/imprisonment.

questions.question: The officer who must sign all **Payment Vouchers** before payments are processed, confirming the correctness and classification of the transaction, is the:
options: Auditor-General
Vote Controller
Head of Accounts
Permanent Secretary
questions.explanation: The Head of Accounts must sign all payment vouchers before payments are processed.

questions.question: The legal instrument enacted by the National Assembly that authorizes the Federal Government to withdraw funds from the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF) for annual expenditure is the:
options: Budget Call Circular
Annual Appropriation Act
Fiscal Responsibility Act
Treasury Circular
questions.explanation: The Annual Appropriation Act is the legal instrument authorizing withdrawal from the CRF for annual expenditure.

questions.question: The primary role of the Internal Auditor is compromised if they report directly to the Minister instead of the Accounting Officer (Permanent Secretary), due to lack of:
options: Loyalty
Funding
Independence and objectivity
Training and skills
questions.explanation: Internal Audit functions must maintain independence and objectivity; reporting to the Accounting Officer ensures accountability within the MDA structure, while ministerial reporting risks political interference.

questions.question: Which PPA Section allows for framework agreements to allow repeated procurements under pre-agreed terms?
options: Section 35
Section 44
Section 42
Section 32
questions.explanation: Section 44 provides for framework agreements.

questions.question: Which principle in the Civil Service requires public officers to serve without seeking personal recognition for policies implemented by the Government?
options: Meritocracy
Anonymity
Delegation
Efficiency
questions.explanation: Anonymity means civil servants serve the government and maintain policy continuity without seeking personal recognition.

questions.question: If an officer is required to present himself for examination by a Medical Board and fails to comply with the instructions, they are liable to be treated as having been:
options: Transferred immediately
Reduced in rank
Absent without leave
Granted sabbatical leave
questions.explanation: An Officer who fails to comply with this rule shall render himself liable to be treated as having been absent without leave (Rule 130307).

questions.question: In a disciplinary investigation involving serious misconduct, the board of inquiry shall consist of not less than:
options: One person
Three persons
Five persons
Seven persons
questions.explanation: The Commission may set up a board of inquiry which shall consist of not less than three persons (Rule 100307(v)).

questions.question: The PPA principle that requires all bidders be treated fairly and equitably is emphasized in:
options: Section 35
Section 16
Section 42
Section 58
questions.explanation: Section 16 requires equal and fair treatment of all bidders during procurement.

questions.question: Section 32 of the PPA mandates transparency in contract awards by requiring:
options: Publication of Ministerial Tenders Board Minutes only
Public access to procurement records and contract awards above thresholds
BPP approval for all low-value contracts
Secret negotiation with contractors
questions.explanation: Section 32 requires publication of contract awards above thresholds and provides for public access to procurement records.

questions.question: An officer involved in procurement fraud, such as collusion or over-invoicing, faces which penalty under the FR and PPA framework?
options: A written warning only
Surcharge and disciplinary query
Dismissal or criminal charges
Transfer to another Ministry
questions.explanation: Officers involved in procurement abuse and fraud face dismissal or criminal charges, as this constitutes serious misconduct (PPA Section 58 / FR Sanctions).

questions.question: The maximum acting appointment period shall not exceed one year, but in exceptional circumstances may be extended for a further period of:
options: Three months
Six months
One year
Two years
questions.explanation: The acting appointment shall not exceed one year, but may be extended for a further period of six months (Rule 020703).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT required to be notified simultaneously of decisions regarding the deferment or withholding of increment (Rule 040209)?
options: The Office of the Accountant General of the Federation
The Permanent Secretary (CMO, OHCSF)
The Office of the Auditor General for the Federation
The Minister of Justice
questions.explanation: Decisions must be communicated to the AGF, AuGF, and the OHCSF [72-74].

questions.question: The final authority to restore a deferred increment, which requires assessing service improvement and conduct, lies with the:
options: Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office
Accountant-General of the Federation
The officer's direct supervisor
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office holds the authority to decide on restoring a deferred increment (Rule 040208).

questions.question: What happens if an Officer who has accepted a course of instruction abroad receives a salary from an employer in the overseas country during the training period?
options: He receives full emolument from Nigeria
He forfeits all Nigerian emoluments/allowances unless specifically approved by the OHCSF
He must refund the cost of the course immediately
He is automatically promoted
questions.explanation: The officer forfeits all Nigerian emoluments/allowances unless specifically approved by the OHCSF.

questions.question: The separation of roles‚Äîauthorization, custody, and recording‚Äîin financial transactions is the first control measure against fraud, known as:

Post-Audit

questions.question: Which system automates payroll, eliminates ghost workers, and tracks civil servant identity records?
options: TSA
GIFMIS
HRMIS
IPPIS
questions.explanation: The Integrated Payroll and Personnel Information System (IPPIS) manages payroll and personnel data, crucial for controlling emoluments and eliminating ghost workers [83-85].

questions.question: The Treasury Single Account (TSA) system was introduced primarily to achieve which of the following financial objectives?
options: Allow MDAs to manage separate bank accounts
Consolidate all government revenue into a single account to improve transparency
Replace the Accountant-General's role
Fund capital projects only
questions.explanation: TSA consolidates government revenues into a single account managed by the CBN to improve transparency and block leakages.

questions.question: The primary objective of Staff Development and training (Rule 070101) is to enhance the knowledge, skills, attitude, effectiveness, and:
options: Political loyalty
Efficiency of staff
Social media presence
Nepotism
questions.explanation: Staff Development aims to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of staff in order to meet their career goals and prepare them for changing duties and responsibilities (Rule 070101).

questions.question: What is the consequence for an officer who fails the compulsory confirmation examination after three consecutive attempts (Rule 030104)?
options: Temporary freeze of salary
Reduction in rank for one year
Required to resign or be withdrawn from the service
Payment of a fine
questions.explanation: An Officer who fails the confirmation examination after three consecutive attempts shall be required to resign or be withdrawn from the service.

questions.question: The compulsory retirement age for all civil servants in the Federal Public Service is:
options: 65 years or 30 years of service
60 years or 35 years of pensionable service, whichever comes first
55 years or 35 years of service
60 years regardless of years of service
questions.explanation: The compulsory retirement age is 60 years or 35 years of pensionable service, whichever comes first (Rule 020909).

questions.question: The primary purpose of **record-keeping** in the Civil Service Handbook is emphasized to ensure:
options: Reduced paper consumption
Accountability and continuity of government operations
Secrecy from the public
Simplified hierarchical structure
questions.explanation: Proper record-keeping ensures accountability, transparency, and continuity in civil service operations.

questions.question: The responsibility for issuing Establishment Circulars that amend, clarify, or interpret the Public Service Rules (PSR) rests with the:
options: National Assembly
Office of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
Attorney-General of the Federation
questions.explanation: Circulars issued by the Head of Service or Presidency update or supplement the rules and provide interim directives.

questions.question: Which administrative body is responsible for handling public complaints against administrative injustice in the public service?
options: Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC)
Public Complaints Commission
Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
Code of Conduct Tribunal (CCT)
questions.explanation: The Public Complaints Commission addresses grievances and promotes administrative justice.

questions.question: The concept of **Meritocracy** in the Civil Service Handbook emphasizes that appointments and promotions must be based on:
options: Political patronage
Age and tenure only
Performance, competence, and vacancy
Seniority over all other factors
questions.explanation: Meritocracy is based on performance, competence, and availability of vacancies.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of discouraging **nepotism** in the Civil Service Handbook?
options: To simplify the recruitment process
To ensure fairness and merit-based appointments
To increase secrecy in appointments
To promote political loyalty
questions.explanation: Nepotism refers to giving undue advantage to family or friends in recruitment and appointments, which the Handbook discourages.

questions.question: The principle of **Transparency** in decision-making requires that:
options: All information is classified
Decisions and processes are open, with records available for accountability
Only the Permanent Secretary knows the budget details
Procurement is conducted secretly
questions.explanation: Transparency requires that decisions and processes are open, with records available for accountability.

questions.question: An officer must discharge every duty assigned to him by Government and accept liability of being stationed wherever his presence is considered to be most useful, as per:
options: Rule 100425 (Private Practice)
Rule 100428 (Posting and Duty Discharge)
Rule 100427 (Seeking Influence)
Rule 100431 (False Statement)
questions.explanation: Rule 100428 mandates the officer's duty to discharge assigned duties and accept liability of being stationed wherever his presence is considered most useful.

questions.question: The primary objective of the Reward and Recognition Scheme (R&RS) in the PSR is to:
options: Replace financial allowances
Institutionalize a culture of excellence and high levels of staff motivation
Increase staff salaries permanently
Fund recreational activities only
questions.explanation: The R&RS System encourages excellence, merit, and high levels of staff motivation (Rule 060103).

questions.question: Who is statutorily designated as the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government?
options: Accountant-General of the Federation (AGF)
Auditor-General for the Federation (AuGF)
Minister of Finance
Director-General, Budget Office
questions.explanation: The Minister of Finance is the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government.

questions.question: The period of service rendered during **study leave without pay** shall be regarded as:
options: A break in service
Not a break in Service
A period of suspension
A period of interdiction
questions.explanation: The period of study shall not be regarded as a break in Service (Rule 120230(b)).

questions.question: The mandatory pre-retirement leave for officers who give notice of retirement is:
options: One month
Two months
Three months
Six months
questions.explanation: The pre-retirement leave is three months before retirement (Rule 120243).

questions.question: The primary role of the Registry Unit in an MDA is to:
options: Conduct internal audits
Manage official files, classification, numbering, and document movement
Process payroll (IPPIS)
Handle disciplinary hearings
questions.explanation: The Registry Unit handles receipt, classification, numbering, and movement of files in an MDA. It is crucial to documentation integrity.

questions.question: The Accountant-General of the Federation is responsible for issuing which key financial instrument that provides detailed instructions on financial procedures and implementation?
options: Appropriation Act
Treasury Circulars
Audit Report
Virement Warrant
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General of the Federation issues Treasury Circulars.

questions.question: In the civil service, **Seniority** is primarily determined by:
options: The age of the officer
Academic qualifications
Grade level and date of promotion/appointment
The geopolitical zone of origin
questions.explanation: Seniority within a grade level is determined by the date of promotion to that grade.

questions.question: The purpose of the **Contingencies Fund** is to cover:
options: Routine overhead expenditure
Emergency and unforeseen government expenditures
Personnel emoluments
Capital projects only
questions.explanation: The Contingencies Fund is used to meet unforeseen and urgent government expenditures [118-120].

questions.question: The statutory standard incremental date for an Officer appointed or promoted to a post in the Federal Public Service shall be:
options: The date of appointment/promotion
The $1^{st}$ January of the year following at least six months of service or promotion
The end of the current quarter
The 31st December of the current year
questions.explanation: The incremental date is the $1^{st}$ January of the year following at least six months of service or promotion (Rule 040203).

questions.question: Which body coordinates and monitors the implementation of the Performance Management System (PMS) across MDAs to ensure national uniformity?
options: Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC)
Office of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF)
Budget Office of the Federation (BOF)
National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC)
questions.explanation: The OHCSF coordinates and monitors the implementation of PMS across MDAs.

questions.question: The goal of promoting **respect for diversity** in the Civil Service Handbook is primarily aimed at achieving:

Compliance with political directives
Reduced accountability
questions.explanation: Respecting diversity fosters inclusivity, unity, and fairness in the workplace.

questions.question: What is the key difference between **withholding** an increment and **deferring** an increment (Rule 040204)?
options: Deferring is a permanent loss; withholding is temporary.
Withholding is a more serious penalty because the loss cannot be restored retrospectively.
Deferring requires FCSC approval; withholding requires only Permanent Secretary approval.
Withholding only applies to GL 06 and below.
questions.explanation: The gravity of the shortcoming determines the penalty, bearing in mind that to withhold an increment is a more serious penalty than to defer it. A withheld increment cannot be restored retroactively.

questions.question: The maximum duration of **study leave with pay** that may be granted to an Officer is:
options: One year
Two years
Three years
Four years
questions.explanation: The duration of study leave with pay shall not exceed two years (Rule 120228(a)).

questions.question: All newly employed Officers must be placed on the **IPPIS platform** within a maximum period of:

One month
Two months of assumption of duty
Six months
questions.explanation: All Officers shall be placed on the IPPIS platform within two months of assumption of duty (Rule 040102).

questions.question: The system used to manage digital HR records, including staff leave, postings, and promotions, is known as:

IPPIS
HRMIS
BPP
questions.explanation: The Human Resource Management Information System (HRMIS) enables digital management of staff records, leave, postings, and promotions.

questions.question: The term **'working hours'** in the PSR definition specifically excludes:

All officially recognized break periods
Preparation time
questions.explanation: The definition of 'working hours' excludes all officially recognized break periods (Rule 16.45).

questions.question: The principle of **Efficiency** in service delivery primarily aims to ensure:

Maximum secrecy in operations
questions.explanation: Efficiency ensures civil servants meet public needs effectively and deliver value for money.

questions.question: The mandatory requirement for promotion eligibility, in addition to merit and seniority, is that the officer must have undergone:

A course on political lobbying
questions.explanation: The officer must have undergone structured training and acquired skill competence as specified in the scheme of service (Rule 020803(a)).

subcategories.name: Access Rights & Obligations (FOI)
subcategories.description: Rights to access public records and institutional obligations.

questions.question: In which year was the Freedom of Information Act enacted in Nigeria?
questions.explanation: The Freedom of Information Act was signed into law in 2011.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Freedom of Information Act?
options: To restrict information flow to foreign entities
To ensure public access to information held by public institutions
To empower only the judiciary in document review
To limit freedom of the press
questions.explanation: The FOI Act aims to make public records accessible to citizens, enhancing transparency and accountability.

questions.question: Under the FOI Act, within how many days must a public institution generally respond to a request for information?
options: 3 days
7 days
14 days
21 days
questions.explanation: Section 4 of the FOI Act stipulates that public institutions must respond to requests within 7 days.

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act guarantees the right of any person to access public records?
options: Section 1
Section 2
Section 4
Section 7
questions.explanation: Section 1 of the FOI Act guarantees the right of any person to access or request information from public institutions.

questions.question: The right of access under the FOI Act extends to:
options: Only Nigerian citizens
Nigerian citizens and registered NGOs only
Any person, including foreign nationals
Only the media
questions.explanation: Section 1 makes the right of access available to 'any person,' not limited to Nigerian citizens.

questions.question: What is the maximum extension period allowed for an FOI request if the initial 7-day period is insufficient?
options: 3 days
7 days
14 days
30 days
questions.explanation: The Act allows a maximum extension of 7 additional days to respond where necessary.

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act requires that information be provided in a language understandable to the applicant, when reasonably practicable?
options: Section 2(3)
Section 3(4)
Section 4(2)
Section 7(1)
questions.explanation: Section 3(4) requires that information be provided in a language understandable to the applicant when reasonably practicable.

questions.question: If a public institution does not hold the requested information but knows another institution does, which section requires the institution to transfer the request?
options: Section 4
Section 5
Section 7
Section 10
questions.explanation: Section 7 provides for transfer of requests where the information is held by another institution.

questions.question: Which section provides for public institutions to charge fees to cover the cost of duplication and transcription of records?
options: Section 5(3)
Section 7(5)
Section 8(1)
Section 9(2)
questions.explanation: Section 8(1) allows institutions to charge fees covering costs of duplication or transcription of records.

questions.question: What is explicitly stated by Section 1(2) regarding the applicant's motivation for requesting information?
options: The applicant must demonstrate financial interest
The applicant must provide strong reasons for the request
No applicant needs to demonstrate interest or reasons
The request must be legally sanctioned
questions.explanation: Section 1(2) makes clear that no applicant needs to demonstrate interest or reasons for requesting information.

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act mandates every public institution to maintain proper records for easy access?
options: Section 2
Section 3
Section 5
Section 6
questions.explanation: Section 2 of the FOI Act mandates public institutions to maintain proper records for easy access.

questions.question: Which section of the FOI Act obliges institutions to proactively publish certain categories of information without waiting for requests?
options: Section 1
Section 2
Section 5
Section 8
questions.explanation: Section 2 requires public institutions to proactively publish categories of information without waiting for requests.

questions.question: The Act requires institutions to train staff on records management and access procedures to ensure:
options: Reduction in staff strength
Reliance on external consultants only
Effective implementation and compliance
Exemption from annual audits
questions.explanation: The Act requires institutions to train staff to ensure effective implementation and compliance.

questions.question: Which section mandates public institutions to submit annual compliance reports on FOI requests to the Attorney-General?
options: Section 2(7)
Section 5(2)
Section 10
Section 30
questions.explanation: Section 2(7) mandates public institutions to submit annual compliance reports on FOI requests to the Attorney-General of the Federation.

questions.question: Which section requires institutions to designate FOI desk officers responsible for handling requests?
options: Section 2(3)
Section 3(4)
Section 5(1)
Section 10(1)
questions.explanation: Section 5(1) requires every institution to designate officers responsible for handling FOI requests.

questions.question: Section 6(2) obliges institutions to maintain records in which format for easy access?
options: Only paper copies
Only in archives
Machine-readable formats
Handwritten formats
questions.explanation: Section 6(2) requires public institutions to keep records in formats that make them easily accessible, such as machine-readable versions.

questions.question: Section 2(3) mandates public institutions to widely disseminate information through various media to the public. This relates to:
options: Exemption procedures
Proactive disclosure
Penalties for non-compliance
Fee calculation
questions.explanation: Section 2(3) mandates wide dissemination of information, aligning with the principle of proactive disclosure.

questions.question: Which section requires public institutions to maintain updated indexes of their records for accessibility?
options: Section 2(2)
Section 3(3)
Section 6(1)
Section 9(1)
questions.explanation: Section 6(1) mandates public institutions to maintain updated indexes of their records for accessibility.

questions.question: Section 2(3) emphasizes the proactive disclosure of which categories of records, even without a formal request?
options: Personal staff medical histories
Cabinet deliberations
Financial records, budgets, and contracts
National security secrets
questions.explanation: Section 2(3) emphasizes proactive disclosure of categories like budgets, contracts, and financial data.

questions.question: If an applicant is denied access, which recourse is available to them under the Act (Section 20)?
options: Resubmit the application after 30 days
Appeal immediately to the Permanent Secretary
File an action in a court of law
Appeal to the Head of Service
questions.explanation: Section 20 provides that applicants may challenge denials of access in a court of law.

questions.question: Who is responsible for oversight and submitting an annual report on FOI compliance to the National Assembly?
options: The Federal Civil Service Commission
The Attorney-General of the Federation
The Auditor-General of the Federation
The Senate President
questions.explanation: The Attorney-General of the Federation is responsible for oversight, issuing guidelines, and submitting an annual report to the National Assembly (Section 32).

questions.question: Which legal entity bears the burden of proof when a request for information is denied?
options: The applicant
The court
The institution denying access
The Attorney-General
questions.explanation: Section 24 places the burden of proof on the institution that denies access to information.

questions.question: What is required of public institutions regarding compliance reports under Section 2(7)?
options: Daily updates to the Minister of Finance
Annual submission to the Attorney-General of the Federation
Quarterly reports to the National Assembly
Verbal confirmation to the Head of Service
questions.explanation: Section 2(7) mandates annual compliance reports to the Attorney-General of the Federation.

questions.question: The fee chargeable under Section 8(1) for fulfilling an FOI request is limited to covering the cost of:
options: Staff time and processing costs
Legal consultation fees
Duplication and transcription of records
Acquisition of new records
questions.explanation: Section 8(1) allows fees covering costs of duplication or transcription of records.

questions.question: Section 5(1) addresses which core institutional capacity requirement for FOI implementation?
options: Financial resource allocation
Designation of FOI desk officers
Proactive publication schedules
Internal audit requirements
questions.explanation: Section 5(1) mandates the designation of officers responsible for handling FOI requests.

questions.question: The right to access public records under Section 1 extends to 'any person', meaning access is not restricted by:
options: Age
Nationality
Gender
All of the above
questions.explanation: The right of access is available to 'any person,' regardless of citizenship, demonstrating universal applicability.

questions.question: If an MDA denies an FOI request, the denial must be accompanied by:
options: A cheque covering the transcription fee
The specific section of the Act justifying the exemption
A non-disclosure agreement
A new request form
questions.explanation: A denial must clearly state the statutory ground for exemption and the section invoked, aligning with procedural compliance (General FOI practice, not explicitly cited in all steps, but derived from the principle of judicial appeal).

questions.question: The FOI Act requires institutions to maintain updated **indexes** of their records primarily to facilitate:

questions.explanation: Section 6(1) mandates indexes for public accessibility and identification of records.

questions.question: Which of these categories is emphasized for **proactive disclosure** under Section 2(3)?
options: Draft policy papers
Internal security memos
Records of all contracts and expenditure
Personnel disciplinary files
questions.explanation: Section 2(3) emphasizes proactive disclosure of categories like budgets, contracts, and financial data.

questions.question: The response time for an FOI request (7 days) is crucial because failure to respond within this period is legally deemed as:
options: An approval of the request
A denial of the request
A waiver of the duplication fee
An invitation for negotiation
questions.explanation: Failure to respond within the statutory time frame is considered a deemed refusal, allowing the applicant recourse to court (Implied by Section 4 and Section 20).

questions.question: Which official has the authority to issue guidelines for the implementation and compliance of the FOI Act?
options: The Senate President
The Federal Civil Service Commission
The Attorney-General of the Federation
The Auditor-General
questions.explanation: The Attorney-General of the Federation issues implementation guidelines and monitors compliance.

questions.question: If a public institution fails to submit its annual compliance report to the Attorney-General, it is in breach of:

Section 5(1)
Section 6(2)
Section 8(1)
questions.explanation: Section 2(7) mandates annual compliance reports submission.

Right to life
Freedom of expression and information (Section 39)
Right to peaceful assembly
questions.explanation: The FOI Act operationalizes the constitutional right to freedom of expression and information (Section 39).

Digital governance and e-service delivery
Secrecy
Political patronage
questions.explanation: Keeping records in easily accessible (machine-readable) formats supports digital governance and efficient service delivery.

questions.question: Under Section 7, if an MDA receives a request for information that primarily concerns another MDA, the receiving MDA must transfer the request within:

3 days
7 days
14 days
questions.explanation: The FOI Act requires requests to be transferred expeditiously, usually within 3 working days (Derived from Section 7 and general FOI implementation guidelines).

If they fail to pay the fee
The right cannot be waived once denied
If the requested record is classified as 'Secret'
questions.explanation: Section 20 grants the right to court action. An applicant may choose not to pursue legal action, effectively waiving the challenge.

An executive committee on secrecy
Only manual records

The Financial Regulations review

The amount of the duplication fee
